question: , What related programs are offered by George Brown College?

context:
Program Name: Cook Apprentice
Code: H601
Credential: George Brown College Certificate
Method of Study: Part-time
Duration: 2–5 years
Starting Months: Open enrolment

Centre: Hospitality & Culinary Arts
School: Chef School
Location: St. James Campus
Program Type: Apprenticeship
Description: Hands-on learning with flexibility and opportunity to earn while studying. Combines in-school learning and paid on-the-job training.
Availability: Fall 2024 (Domestic students only), Open; Winter 2025, not available; Spring 2025, Open (Domestic students only)
Related Programs: Culinary Skills (H134), Culinary Management (H100), Baker / Patissier Apprentice Program (H600)

The Cook Apprenticeship program at George Brown College offers two levels of in-school training: Level I (H601) and Level II (H607).

Level I (H601):
- Focuses on fundamental culinary skills and theories required to be a cook in a modern kitchen.
- Includes management practices such as kitchen management and business development.
- Leads to earning the official Red Seal certification as a cook from the Ontario Ministry of Labour, Immigration, Training and Skills Development (MLITSD).
- Required courses: HOSF 6123 (Business Development – Basic), HOSF 6124 (Kitchen Management – Basic), HOSF 6125 (Food Theory – Basic), HOSF 6126 (Culinary Techniques – Basic), HOSF 6127 (Bake Theory), HOSF 6128 (Techniques of Baking – Basic), HOSF 6143 (Basic Nutrition), and HOSF 6161 (Sanitation, Safety and Equipment).

Level II (H607):
- Develops advanced culinary skills and the management practices required to become a kitchen leader.
- Also leads to earning the official Red Seal certification as a cook from the Ontario Ministry of Labour, Immigration, Training and Skills Development (MLITSD).

Apprenticeship training is administered by the Apprenticeship Client Services Branch of the Ontario Ministry of Labour, Immigration, Training and Skills Development (MLITSD).

Graduates can pursue a rewarding career as a cook in various settings such as restaurants, hotel dining rooms, cafés, hospitals, clubs and resorts, spas, and catering companies.

question: , In which settings can graduates find job opportunities after completing the Cook Apprenticeship program?

context:
The Cook Apprenticeship program at George Brown College offers two levels of in-school training: Level I (H601) and Level II (H607).

Level I (H601):
- Focuses on fundamental culinary skills and theories required to be a cook in a modern kitchen.

Graduates can pursue a rewarding career as a cook in various settings such as restaurants, hotel dining rooms, cafés, hospitals, clubs and resorts, spas, and catering companies.

Programs Offered:
- Business Development – Advanced (HOSF 6134)
- Kitchen Management – Advanced (HOSF 6135)
- Food Theory – Advanced (HOSF 6136)
- Culinary Techniques – Advanced (HOSF 6137)
- Techniques of Baking – Advanced (HOSF 6138)

Tuition & Fees:
- Classroom fee for one level of the program in Fall 2023: $678.00
- Additional costs (subject to change): Uniform ($290), Knives and small wares ($500–$700), Books ($400–$600), Black safety shoes ($110–$160)

Admission Requirements:
- Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent
- grade 12 English (C or U)
- grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U)
- Registered as an apprentice with the Ontario Ministry of Labour, Immigration, Training and Skills Development (MLITSD)
- Have a registered employer sponsor
- Mature Student status (19 years of age or older)

Course Exemptions:
- Certain Ontario Academic Credit (OAC), college or university credits may qualify for course exemptions.

Health Policy:
- Various allergens, including nuts, dairy and shellfish, are used in practical labs.
- George Brown College is sensitive to religious observances but may not meet specific dietary laws related to halal and kosher foods.

To Apply:
- Visit Apprenticeship in Ontario to learn more.
- Register as a cook apprentice with the Ontario Ministry of Labour, Immigration, Training and Skills Development (MLITSD).

question: , What are the additional costs associated with these advanced programs (Uniform, Knives and small wares, Books, Black safety shoes)?

context:
Programs Offered:
- Business Development – Advanced (HOSF 6134)
- Kitchen Management – Advanced (HOSF 6135)
- Food Theory – Advanced (HOSF 6136)
- Culinary Techniques – Advanced (HOSF 6137)
- Techniques of Baking – Advanced (HOSF 6138)

Tuition & Fees:
- Classroom fee for one level of the program in Fall 2023: $678.00
- Additional costs (subject to change): Uniform ($290), Knives and small wares ($500–$700), Books ($400–$600), Black safety shoes ($110–$160)

Admission Requirements:
- Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent
- grade 12 English (C or U)
- grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U)
- Registered as an apprentice with the Ontario Ministry of Labour, Immigration, Training and Skills Development (MLITSD)
- Have a registered employer sponsor
- Mature Student status (19 years of age or older)

Course Exemptions:
- Certain Ontario Academic Credit (OAC), college or university credits may qualify for course exemptions.

Health Policy:
- Various allergens, including nuts, dairy and shellfish, are used in practical labs.
- George Brown College is sensitive to religious observances but may not meet specific dietary laws related to halal and kosher foods.

To Apply:
- Visit Apprenticeship in Ontario to learn more.
- Register as a cook apprentice with the Ontario Ministry of Labour, Immigration, Training and Skills Development (MLITSD).

- Register as a cook apprentice with the Ontario Ministry of Labour, Immigration, Training and Skills Development (MLITSD).

To become a cook apprentice at George Brown College, you must:
1. Be registered as a cook apprentice with the Ontario Ministry of Labour, Immigration, Training and Skills Development (MLITSD).
2. Have a registered employer sponsor.
3. Have at least one year of industry experience.
4. Have an Ontario Secondary School Diploma with credits at or above the general level, or qualify for mature student status.

Contact information:
- Toronto office of Ministry of Labour, Immigration, Training and Skills Development (Apprenticeship): 14th Floor, 400 University Avenue, Toronto, Ontario M7A 1T7; phone: 416-326-7600.
- CHCAStudentSupport@georgebrown.ca for general Chef School inquiries.
- Contact Centre of George Brown College: phone 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559), or long distance 1-800-265-2002.

Programs offered:
- Cook Apprentice Program (H601)
- Culinary Skills (H134)
- Culinary Management (H100)
- Baker / Patissier Apprentice Program (H600)

Ways to get more information:
- Sign up for Open House Discovery Day
- Book campus tour
- Book info session
- Sign up to receive tailored resources for application process.
